case_name: Sohel Singh, Waryam Singh and Shiv Singh v. Amar Singh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 492 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 492 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the, judgment and order dated September 12, 1955, of the Punjab High Court, Chandigarh, in Regular Second Appeal No. 747 of 1951.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 12, 1955 of Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 747 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the, judgment and order dated September 12, 1955, of the Punjab High Court, Chandigarh, in Regular Second Appeal No. 747 of 1951. Achhru Bam and K. L. Mehta, for the appellants. M. Lal and Mohan Lal Aggarwal, for respondents Nos. 1 to 4. 1961. March 6.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on March 6, 1961 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 6. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, , J.-This appeal arises out of the judgment and order of the High Court of the Punjab reversing in second appeal the decree of the District Court and thus dismissing the plaintiffs suit for declaration.

facts.text: Punjab High Court reversed the decree of the District Court in second appeal and dismissed the plaintiffs' suit for declaration.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of the judgment and order of the High Court of the Punjab reversing in second appeal the decree of the District Court and thus dismissing the plaintiffs suit for declaration. In order to understand the question in companytroversy it is necessary to set out the following pedigree Milkhi Himmat Singh Gulab Singh Mehtab Singh Fattu  dead  Leekar dead  Mangal Singh Lalu Sheru Nathu Singh  testator   dead   dead  Harnam Singh Sohel Singh Waryam Singh  Plaintiff No. 1   Plaintiff NO. 2  Karnail Ajaib Amar Shiv Puran Singh Singh Singh Singh Singh  deft.NO.3   deft.NO.2   deft.No.1   PHf.NO.3   deft.NO.4

facts.text: Mangal Singh executed a will on August 11, 1947 bequeathing the property in dispute to Amar Singh defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: On August, 11 1947 Mangal Singh executed a will bequeathing the property in dispute to Amar Singh defendant No. 1. After the death of Mangal Singh on October 25, 1947 the mutation of his estate was effected in the name of Amar Singh on April.10, 1948 by mutation No. 733.

facts.text: Mangal Singh died on October 25, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Mangal Singh on October 25, 1947 the mutation of his estate was effected in the name of Amar Singh on April.10, 1948 by mutation No. 733. The plaintiffs Sohel Singh, Waryam Singh and Shiv Singh brought a suit for dec- laration that the will was ineffective against them and for possession of certain parcels of land mutated in the name of Amar Singh.

facts.text: Mutation of Mangal Singh's estate effected in the name of Amar Singh on April 10, 1948 by mutation No. 733.

anchor.surface_text: the mutation of his estate was effected in the name of Amar Singh on April.10, 1948 by mutation No. 733. The plaintiffs Sohel Singh, Waryam Singh and Shiv Singh brought a suit for dec- laration that the will was ineffective against them and for possession of certain parcels of land mutated in the name of Amar Singh. The allegation was that the will was made under undue influence, companyrcion and fraud and that Mangal Singh had numberpower to make the will as the land in dispute was ancestral qua the defendants.

facts.text: Plaintiffs Sohel Singh, Waryam Singh and Shiv Singh brought a suit for declaration that the will was ineffective against them and for possession of certain parcels of land.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs Sohel Singh, Waryam Singh and Shiv Singh brought a suit for dec- laration that the will was ineffective against them and for possession of certain parcels of land mutated in the name of Amar Singh. The allegation was that the will was made under undue influence, companyrcion and fraud and that Mangal Singh had numberpower to make the will as the land in dispute was ancestral qua the defendants. These allegations were denied and requisite issues were raised.

facts.text: Plaintiffs alleged that the will was made under undue influence, coercion and fraud.

anchor.surface_text: The allegation was that the will was made under undue influence, companyrcion and fraud and that Mangal Singh had numberpower to make the will as the land in dispute was ancestral qua the defendants. These allegations were denied and requisite issues were raised. The suit was dismissed by the trial companyrt holding that it was number proved that the execution of the will was procured by the exercise of undue influence or companyrcion or fraud and that the land had number been proved to be ancestral.

facts.text: Plaintiffs alleged that Mangal Singh had no power to make the will as the land was ancestral qua the defendants.

anchor.surface_text: and that Mangal Singh had numberpower to make the will as the land in dispute was ancestral qua the defendants. These allegations were denied and requisite issues were raised. The suit was dismissed by the trial companyrt holding that it was number proved that the execution of the will was procured by the exercise of undue influence or companyrcion or fraud and that the land had number been proved to be ancestral.

facts.text: Trial court dismissed the suit holding that execution of the will was not procured by undue influence, coercion or fraud and land not proved ancestral.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the trial companyrt holding that it was number proved that the execution of the will was procured by the exercise of undue influence or companyrcion or fraud and that the land had number been proved to be ancestral. An appeal was taken against this decree to the District Judge who held that out of 66 Kanals, 2 Marlas of land in dispute an area of 28 Kanals, 3 Marlas was ancestral as it was held by Himmat Singh, father of Mehtab Singh the companymon ancestor.

facts.text: District Judge held that out of 66 Kanals 2 Marlas of land, 28 Kanals 3 Marlas was ancestral as held by Himmat Singh, father of Mehtab Singh.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was taken against this decree to the District Judge who held that out of 66 Kanals, 2 Marlas of land in dispute an area of 28 Kanals, 3 Marlas was ancestral as it was held by Himmat Singh, father of Mehtab Singh the companymon ancestor. The District Judge also held that Mehtab Singh had predeceased Himmat Singh but of this there seems to be numberproof.

facts.text: District Judge held Mehtab Singh predeceased Himmat Singh but no proof.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge also held that Mehtab Singh had predeceased Himmat Singh but of this there seems to be numberproof. On appeal the High Court reversed the judgment of the District Judge ,nd restored that of the trial companyrt and the appellants have companye in appeal to this companyrt by special leave.

facts.text: High Court reversed District Judge and restored trial court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the High Court reversed the judgment of the District Judge ,nd restored that of the trial companyrt and the appellants have companye in appeal to this companyrt by special leave. The sole question for decision in this appeal is whether 28 Kanals 3 Marlas out of the land in suit by the appellant.-, is proved to be ancestral qua them.

facts.text: Sole question: whether 28 Kanals 3 Marlas of land proved ancestral qua appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question for decision in this appeal is whether 28 Kanals 3 Marlas out of the land in suit by the appellant.-, is proved to be ancestral qua them. Out of the land claimed 20 Kanals 19 Marlas described in Para A-2 had been proved to have been acquired by Mangal Singh by preemption and another portion was his self-acquired mortgagee land.

facts.text: 20 Kanals 19 Marlas described in Para A-2 acquired by Mangal Singh by preemption.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the land claimed 20 Kanals 19 Marlas described in Para A-2 had been proved to have been acquired by Mangal Singh by preemption and another portion was his self-acquired mortgagee land. Therefore the dispute was companyfined to certain Khasra numbers which had fallen-to the share of the testator in companysolidation proceedings in lieu of his share in land held by him.

facts.text: Some Khasra numbers traced to possession of Himmat Singh son of Milkhi in 1849 per excerpt P.W. 6/1.

anchor.surface_text: The excerpt P.W. 6/1 prepared by the Special Kanugo shows that some of those Khasra numbers were traced to the possession of Himmat Singh s o Milkhi in 1849 and some Khasra numbers were traced to the possession of Himmat Singh and others and the remaining were traced to strangers.

facts.text: District Judge decreed suit for 28 Kanals 3 Marlas land held by Himmat Singh in 1849.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge held that only the land which was held in 1849 by Himmat Singh companyld be ancestral qua the plaintiffs and therefore decreed the suit in regard to that portion which was 28 Kanals and 3 Marlas and that is the area of the land which is number in dispute.

facts.text: At first regular settlement, the land decreed was held by Himmat Singh.

anchor.surface_text: At the first regular settlement the land decreed was held by Himmat Singh and the revenue pedigree shows that in 1885 the three branches descending from Himmat Singh, i.e., Gulab Singh who was alive, sons of Mehtab Singh and Leekar son of Fattu held khewat Nos. 34, 35 and 36 which were equal in area and each branch was paying land revenue of Rs. 13.

facts.text: In 1885 revenue pedigree, three branches from Himmat Singh held khewat Nos. 34, 35, 36 equal area, each paying Rs. 13 land revenue.

anchor.surface_text: and the revenue pedigree shows that in 1885 the three branches descending from Himmat Singh, i.e., Gulab Singh who was alive, sons of Mehtab Singh and Leekar son of Fattu held khewat Nos. 34, 35 and 36 which were equal in area and each branch was paying land revenue of Rs. 13. The excerpt Ex. W. 6/1 prepared by the Kanungo further shows that the land held by the sons of Mehtab Singh, i. e., Khata No. 34 was held by them jointly and in equal shares.

facts.text: Khata No. 34 held jointly and in equal shares by sons of Mehtab Singh per Ex. PW 6/1.

anchor.surface_text: The excerpt Ex. W. 6/1 prepared by the Kanungo further shows that the land held by the sons of Mehtab Singh, i. e., Khata No. 34 was held by them jointly and in equal shares. On these facts the finding in regard to the land decreed was held to be ancestral.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the 28 Kanals 3 Marlas land to be ancestral qua the plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: the history of the land which has been referred to above clearly shows the ancestral nature of the land in the hand of the descendants, the parties to the present appeal. It therefore is ancestral.

facts.text: High Court erred in interfering with District Judge's finding on ancestral land.

anchor.surface_text: In order to companye to this companyclusion the learned District Judge in an elaborate judgment has traced the history of each Khasura number and decreed only those Khasras which were held by Himmat Singh. The High Court did number accept this finding but, in our opinion, the High Court was in error in interfering with that finding.

facts.text: Land consolidated; in lieu of ancestral and non-ancestral, consolidated area given; portion corresponding to ancestral remains ancestral.

anchor.surface_text: Where land has been companysolidated and in lieu of ancestral lands and number- ancestral land a companysolidated area is given to a proprietor then such of the portion of the companysolidated area which companyresponds to the area of land which was ancestral will be ancestral land.

issues.text: The sole question for decision in this appeal is whether 28 Kanals 3 Marlas out of the land in suit claimed by the appellants is proved to be ancestral qua them

anchor.surface_text: The sole question for decision in this appeal is whether 28 Kanals 3 Marlas out of the land in suit by the appellant.-, is proved to be ancestral qua them.

issues.text: whether the land can be considered ancestral qua the plaintiffs even if revenue records do not show possession by the immediate common ancestor Mehtab Singh but by his father Himmat Singh with history indicating inheritance without self-acquisition

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the respondents that the land was number ancestral and that it cannot be ancestral unless it was shown that it was held by the companymon ancestor, i. e., Mehtab Singh and as there was numberrevenue entry showing the land to have been held by him the land companyld number be said to be ancestral.

issues.text: whether after consolidation of ancestral and non-ancestral land the consolidated holding loses ancestral character or retains it pro rata corresponding to the ancestral portion

anchor.surface_text: It was then argued that as the land claimed had been companysolidated and both ancestral and number-ancestral land had got mixed up it cannot be said as to what portion is ancestral and what is number-ancestral. This again is number a companyrect approach to the question. Where land has been companysolidated and in lieu of ancestral lands and number- ancestral land a companysolidated area is given to a proprietor then such of the portion of the companysolidated area which companyresponds to the area of land which was ancestral will be ancestral land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: District Judge elaborately traced history of each Khasra number held by Himmat Singh

holdings.text: The history of the land clearly shows the ancestral nature of the 28 Kanals 3 Marlas land in the hands of the descendants, the parties to the appeal. It therefore is ancestral qua them

anchor.surface_text: the history of the land which has been referred to above clearly shows the ancestral nature of the land in the hand of the descendants, the parties to the present appeal. It therefore is ancestral.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue records from 1849 trace possession to Himmat Singh, equal shares to three branches in 1885 including sons of Mehtab Singh

holdings.text: It is an erroneous view that land cannot be ancestral merely because possession by the immediate common ancestor (Mehtab Singh) is not shown in revenue records, but only by a more remote direct ancestor (Himmat Singh), where history gives no indication of self-acquisition but only inheritance

anchor.surface_text: But this does number support the submission of companynsel for the respondents. It is true that in the present case the land was hold by a remote ancestor and number by the immediate companymon ancestor but the history of the land which has been referred to above clearly shows the ancestral nature of the land in the hand of the descendants, the parties to the present appeal. It therefore is ancestral. The companytention of the respondents does number find support from decided cases and it is an erroneous view to take that merely because the possession by the companymon ancestor itself is number shown in the revenue records but that of a more remote direct ancestor is it is number-ancestral even though the history of the land gives numberindication of its acquisition by the descendants except by inheritance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Privy Council in Attar Singh v. Thakar Singh requires land to come by descent from lineal male ancestor through whom claimants trace; here history confirms inheritance without self-acquisition

holdings.text: Where land has been consolidated and in lieu of ancestral lands and non-ancestral land a consolidated area is given to a proprietor then such of the portion of the consolidated area which corresponds to the area of land which was ancestral will be ancestral land

anchor.surface_text: Where land has been companysolidated and in lieu of ancestral lands and number- ancestral land a companysolidated area is given to a proprietor then such of the portion of the companysolidated area which companyresponds to the area of land which was ancestral will be ancestral land.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correct approach rejects argument that mixing in consolidation obliterates identifiability; follows precedent in Haveldar Mihan Singh v. Piara Singh

precedents.citation: Attar Singh, v. Thakar Singh 1 1908 L.R. 35 I.A. 2o6,211

anchor.surface_text: Support for this was sought from a judgment of the Privy Council in Attar Singh, v. Thakar Singh 1  where Lord Collins observed as follows- It is through their father, as heir of the abovenamed Dhanna Singh, that the plaintiffs claimed, and unless the lands came to Dhanna Singh by descent from a lineal male ancestor in the male line through whom the plaintiffs also in like manner claimed, they are numberdeemed ancestral in Hindu law. But this does number support the submission of companynsel for the respondents. It is true that in the present case the land was hold by a remote ancestor and number by the immediate companymon ancestor but the history of the land which has been referred to above clearly shows the ancestral nature of the land in the hand of the descendants, the parties to the present appeal. It therefore is ancestral. The companytention of the respondents does number find support from decided cases and it is an erroneous view to take that merely because the possession by the companymon ancestor itself is number shown in the revenue records but that of a more remote direct ancestor is it is number-ancestral even though the history of the land gives numberindication of its acquisition by the descendants except by inheritance.  1   1908  L.R. 35 I.A. 2o6,211.

precedents.cited_proposition: lands are not deemed ancestral unless they came to the father by descent from a lineal male ancestor in the male line
precedents.cited_holding: It is through their father, as heir of the abovenamed Dhanna Singh, that the plaintiffs claimed, and unless the lands came to Dhanna Singh by descent from a lineal male ancestor in the male line through whom the plaintiffs also in like manner claimed, they are numberdeemed ancestral in Hindu law.

precedents.citation: Haveldar Mihan Singh v. Piara Singh 1

anchor.surface_text: It was then argued that as the land claimed had been companysolidated and both ancestral and number-ancestral land had got mixed up it cannot be said as to what portion is ancestral and what is number-ancestral. This again is number a companyrect approach to the question. Where land has been companysolidated and in lieu of ancestral lands and number- ancestral land a companysolidated area is given to a proprietor then such of the portion of the companysolidated area which companyresponds to the area of land which was ancestral will be ancestral land. It was so held in Haveldar Mihan Singh v. Piara Singh 1  which is a decision of Abdul Rashid and Mehr Chand Mahajan, JJ.

precedents.case_name: Haveldar Mihan Singh v Piara Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: in consolidation proceedings, the portion of consolidated area corresponding to ancestral land remains ancestral
